metadata.description: This dataset includes data recorded by the Qinghai Lake integrated observatory network obtained from phenology camera observation data of the Alpine meadow and grassland ecosystem Superstation from May 1 in 2019 to December 31 in 2019. The site (98°35′41.62″E, 37°42′11.47″N) was located in the alpine meadow and alpine grassland ecosystem, near the SuGe Road in Tianjun County, Qinghai Province. The elevation is 3718m. The phenology camera adopts a vertical downward method to collect data, with the resolution of 2592*1944. Phenology photos in this data set were taken at 12:10 a day, which has a time error of ±10 min. The image is named as BSDCJZ BEIJING_IR_Year_Month_Day_Time.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

Verification.Question: Is the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model applicable for estimating evapotranspiration in areas with heterogeneous soil and vegetation temperatures?

Disjunctive.Question: For a dataset focusing on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which temporal sampling strategy is more effective: continuous daily measurements, specific days of the year, or seasonal snapshots?

Concept Completion.Question: When is the phenology camera data collected each day, and what is the time accuracy?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to estimate evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes with mixed soil and vegetation?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used involves field observations from a superstation equipped with a boundary layer tower. This includes a combination of meteorological parameters, radiations, and turbulent fluxes measured at various heights, supplemented by thermal infrared camera images collected on a high platform to capture soil and canopy component temperatures.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when measuring evapotranspiration in arid regions, and how is it addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge in arid regions is the effectiveness of composite temperature separation approaches, particularly when errors arise from image classification due to varying vegetation abundance. This is addressed by accurately classifying soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method and validating component temperatures with radiometric temperatures derived from long-wave radiation observations.

Definition.Question: What is the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model used for in the context of vegetation-covered land?
Definition.Answer: The TSEB model is used to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation. It is particularly important for applications related to the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges faced with one-source evapotranspiration estimation models in heterogeneous landscapes?
Definition.Answer: One-source models combine soil and vegetation components into a single source, which is problematic in heterogeneous landscapes where soil and vegetation have different temperatures and resistances to energy exchange. This makes it difficult for these models to accurately estimate surface evapotranspiration.

Definition.Question: How are soil and canopy component temperatures used in the TSEB model to improve the accuracy of E, T, and ET estimations?
Definition.Answer: Soil and canopy component temperatures are observed using a high-resolution thermal camera and used as inputs to the TSEB model. This approach improves the validation of E, T, and ET estimations by using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and comparisons with eddy covariance system measurements.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using ground-measured soil and canopy temperatures compared to composite temperature separation approaches in heterogeneous landscapes?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-measured soil and canopy temperatures provide direct observations, reducing uncertainties in estimating E, T, and ET, whereas composite temperature separation approaches face challenges such as image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance and can lead to overestimations of component temperatures. These classification errors can affect the accuracy of temperature estimates in heterogeneous landscapes.

Comparison.Question: How does the application of the TSEB model using ground-based measurements differ from its application using satellite-based data in terms of data requirements and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: The application of the TSEB model using ground-based measurements, such as those from the Daman superstation, involves detailed direct observations of soil and canopy temperatures, which improve the accuracy of E, T, and ET estimations. In contrast, satellite-based applications often face limitations due to the unavailability of required parameters and observations, potentially reducing accuracy due to the need to infer component temperatures from composite radiometric data.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of high-resolution thermal cameras and ground-based measurements enhance the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates in strongly advective environments?
Interpretation.Answer: High-resolution thermal cameras and ground-based measurements can enhance evapotranspiration estimates by providing detailed soil and canopy temperature data, which are crucial for refining component separation in models. This approach allows for more accurate quantification of latent heat fluxes and energy balance, particularly in environments where advective conditions influence temperature and moisture dynamics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in arid regions using composite temperature separation approaches?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in arid regions using composite temperature separation approaches are primarily due to errors in image classification, which vary with vegetation abundance. This includes the misclassification of soil pixels as vegetation pixels, leading to overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, as well as uncertainties in incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy, further complicate accurate Rn estimation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to measure evaporation and transpiration on the ground in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Measuring evaporation (E) and transpiration (T) on the ground in heterogeneous landscapes is difficult because the surface is a mix of soil and vegetation, each with different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. This heterogeneity complicates the use of one-source models for accurate evapotranspiration estimation, as these models cannot account for the distinct energy exchanges occurring above the canopy and the soil.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the increased uncertainty of the TSEB model in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The increased uncertainty of the TSEB model in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is mainly due to the uncertainty in the surface–air temperature difference, which can dominate errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the composite radiometric temperature. Additionally, the strong advective environment contributes to these uncertainties, affecting the model's performance in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data accuracy when using high-resolution thermal cameras for collecting soil and canopy component temperatures in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-resolution thermal cameras to collect soil and canopy component temperatures allows for more accurate separation of latent fluxes of soil and vegetation components. It helps achieve reasonable accuracy in estimating the ratios of evaporation and transpiration (E/ET% and T/ET%) and latent heat fluxes, despite the challenges posed by strongly advective conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of implementing phenocam observations at a mixed superstation in the Qinghai Lake Basin, and how do these observations contribute to understanding surface processes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The phenocam observations at the mixed superstation in the Qinghai Lake Basin are intended to capture detailed phenological changes in high-altitude grassland ecosystems by collecting high-resolution images. These observations help in understanding the dynamic surface processes by providing data on vegetation growth patterns and transitions over time, which are crucial for modeling and managing the terrestrial water cycle and related resources.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of integrating stable isotope techniques with eddy covariance measurements in the validation of evapotranspiration models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of stable isotope techniques with eddy covariance measurements aims to enhance the validation of evapotranspiration models by providing a detailed assessment of the partitioning between evaporation and transpiration. This combination helps in accurately quantifying these components, which is essential for improving model reliability and ensuring precise water resource management strategies in various climatic and vegetation conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures for using a phenology camera to capture daily observations in high-altitude grassland areas, and how is the data managed for consistency over time?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A phenology camera is set up to capture images of the grassland area every day at 12:10 PM, with a time accuracy of ±10 minutes. The camera is positioned vertically downward to ensure consistent framing and image quality. Images are taken at a resolution of 2592x1944 and are systematically named according to a specific format that includes the date and time of capture for easy retrieval and analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model implemented to estimate evaporation and transpiration using soil and canopy temperatures, and what are the steps for validating these estimates?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The TSEB model is implemented by using ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures as inputs. These temperatures are obtained from high-resolution thermal images captured by a thermal infrared camera. The model estimates evaporation and transpiration, which are then validated using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique and eddy covariance (EC) measurements. The validation involves comparing the estimated ratios of evaporation and transpiration to evapotranspiration (E/ET% and T/ET%) against observed values.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What techniques are used to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration components in heterogeneous land surfaces, and what data collection methods support this partitioning?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Evapotranspiration is partitioned into evaporation and transpiration components using the TSEB model, which requires soil and canopy component temperatures derived from thermal images. The partitioning is supported by meteorological data collected from boundary layer towers, which include air temperature, wind speed, humidity, four-component radiations, and turbulent fluxes. The Craig–Gordon model is applied to ground-based measurements to further support this partitioning.

Enablement.Question: What conditions facilitated the successful application of the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in estimating evaporation and transpiration for vegetated land?
Enablement.Answer: The successful application of the TSEB model was facilitated by improvements in estimating soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, fractional vegetation coverage, and surface component temperatures. The model's requirement for only a single measurement of land surface temperature while using the surface energy balance also contributed to its wide applicability across various vegetation types, climates, and spatial scales.

Enablement.Question: What factors enable the separation of latent fluxes of soil and vegetation components in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area using the TSEB model?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, obtained from high-precision thermal infrared cameras, enable the separation of latent fluxes of soil and vegetation components. Validation of the TSEB model with stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques and ground-based measurements further supports the reliable estimation of these fluxes, even in strongly advection-irrigated agricultural areas.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to obtain accurate estimations of evapotranspiration in arid regions using existing data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: In arid regions, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in effectiveness, leading to errors, as image classification errors affect the estimation of soil and canopy temperatures. These errors, along with uncertainties in atmospheric radiation and transmittance, contribute to inaccurate estimations of evapotranspiration.

Expectation.Question: Why might data from ground-based measurements, such as the eddy covariance system, not meet expected energy balance closure in irrigated areas?
Expectation.Answer: In irrigated agricultural areas, achieving energy balance closure is challenging due to the incomplete measurement of energy fluxes like H and LE, which can be influenced by the strong advective environment. The uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences further complicates the accuracy of these measurements.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the methodologies used for data collection in high-altitude phenological observation and its potential impact on dataset quality?
Judgmental.Answer: The methodology involves using phenological cameras with vertically downward data acquisition at high resolutions. The consistent timing of image capture (around 12:10 daily) and specific naming conventions for images suggest a structured approach to data collection. This can enhance the quality and reliability of datasets by providing consistent and high-resolution data, though it requires careful management of time discrepancies within ±10 minutes.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the data collection method ensures accuracy in measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection method incorporates a two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, which requires accurate measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures. To ensure accuracy, ground-measured temperatures are used in combination with a high-resolution thermal camera and validated against stable isotope techniques and eddy covariance measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore data collection methods used to capture high-resolution thermal images for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the field, high-resolution thermal images for estimating evapotranspiration are captured using a manually operated Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera on a boundary layer tower. Measurements are taken approximately every 120 minutes from 07:00 to 19:00 CST during the daytime.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that can be used to assess the performance of two-source energy balance models in predicting evapotranspiration over agricultural areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential dataset for assessing the performance of two-source energy balance models includes data from the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE). This dataset contains measurements of evapotranspiration and the ratios of evaporation and transpiration in an artificial oasis covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards.
